name: Ionian (Major Scale)
notes_in_c: C D E F G A B
description: The major scale — the foundation of Western music theory. All other modes and scales are typically described in relation to this scale.
common_usage: Use over major 7th chords functioning as the I chord. The most consonant scale choice for major tonality.

name: Dorian
notes_in_c: C D Eb F G A Bb
description: The 2nd mode of the major scale. The natural 6th degree distinguishes it from natural minor (Aeolian), giving it a brighter, less melancholic minor sound. The most commonly used minor mode in jazz.
common_usage: The default scale for minor 7th chords in jazz, especially as the ii chord in a ii-V-I. Also used extensively in funk, soul, and fusion.

name: Mixolydian
notes_in_c: C D E F G A Bb
description: The 5th mode of the major scale. Identical to the major scale except for the b7, which gives it the dominant 7th quality. The natural scale choice for unaltered dominant 7th chords.
common_usage: Use over dominant 7th chords resolving down a 5th (standard V7-I resolution). The primary scale for blues and rock dominant chords.

name: Aeolian (Natural Minor)
notes_in_c: C D Eb F G Ab Bb
description: The natural minor scale — the 6th mode of major. The b6 distinguishes it from Dorian and gives it a darker, more melancholic character.
common_usage: Use over minor 7th chords when a darker color is desired, especially as a vi chord or in minor key progressions where the b6 is present in the harmony.

name: Lydian
notes_in_c: C D E F# G A B
description: The 4th mode of the major scale. The #4 is the defining note — it removes the only 'avoid note' (natural 4) present in Ionian, making every note in Lydian consonant over a major 7th chord.
common_usage: A jazz favorite over major 7th chords, especially when the chord is NOT the I chord (e.g., IVmaj7). Pat Metheny's signature sound. Also used over maj7#11 chords.

name: Phrygian
notes_in_c: C Db Eb F G Ab Bb
description: The 3rd mode of the major scale. The b2 gives it a distinctive Spanish/Middle Eastern flavor. In jazz, it's used sparingly because the b2 can clash with standard minor 7th chord voicings.
common_usage: Flamenco and Spanish-influenced music. In jazz, sometimes used over a iii chord or for a specific color. Also used in metal and prog rock.

name: Locrian
notes_in_c: C Db Eb F Gb Ab Bb
description: The 7th and darkest mode of the major scale. The b5 makes it the natural choice for half-diminished (m7b5) chords. The most unstable of the modes — it has no perfect 5th.
common_usage: Use over m7b5 (half-diminished) chords, especially as the ii chord in minor key ii-V-i progressions.

name: Melodic Minor (ascending)
notes_in_c: C D Eb F G A B
description: The jazz melodic minor scale — ascending and descending with the same notes (unlike classical melodic minor). It's like a major scale with a b3, or a Dorian with a natural 7. This scale is the parent of some of the most important jazz scales (Lydian Dominant, Altered, Locrian #2).
common_usage: Over minor(maj7) and minor 6 chords (tonic minor function). The parent scale of the altered scale, Lydian dominant, and more.

name: Lydian Dominant (Lydian b7)
notes_in_c: C D E F# G A Bb
description: The 4th mode of melodic minor. Combines Lydian's #4 brightness with Mixolydian's b7 dominant quality. This is THE scale for tritone substitution — when you play a bII7 resolving to I, Lydian Dominant is the correct scale.
common_usage: Over 7#11 chords, tritone substitutions (bII7), and IV7 chords in blues. A signature sound in modern jazz.

name: Altered Scale (Super Locrian)
formula: 1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7
notes_in_c: C Db D# E Gb Ab Bb
description: The 7th mode of melodic minor and one of the most important scales in jazz. It contains ALL altered tensions: b9, #9, #11(b5), b13(#5). When jazz musicians say 'play the altered scale,' this is what they mean. The enharmonic respelling shows how it maps to a dominant chord: 1 b9 #9 3 b5 #5 b7.
common_usage: Over any altered dominant chord (7alt, 7b9, 7#9, 7#5b9, etc.). The go-to scale for V7 chords when you want maximum tension before resolving to I. Essential for bebop and post-bop styles.

name: Locrian #2 (Locrian Natural 2)
notes_in_c: C D Eb F Gb Ab Bb
description: The 6th mode of melodic minor. Like Locrian but with a natural 2nd instead of b2. This makes it smoother and more usable than standard Locrian over m7b5 chords. Many jazz educators (Mark Levine, etc.) recommend this as the default m7b5 scale.
character: Dark but smoother than Locrian, sophisticated
common_usage: Over m7b5 (half-diminished) chords as a more sophisticated alternative to Locrian. Especially useful in minor ii-V-i progressions.

name: Whole Tone Scale
notes_in_c: C D E F# G# Bb
description: A symmetric scale built entirely of whole steps. There are only 2 unique whole tone scales. It has a dreamy, ungrounded, almost otherworldly quality because there's no half-step tension. Used by Debussy, Monk, and Wayne Shorter.
common_usage: Over augmented dominant chords (7#5). Creates a distinctive, ethereal sound. Use sparingly for maximum effect.

name: Half-Whole Diminished
notes_in_c: C Db Eb E F# G A Bb
description: An 8-note symmetric scale alternating half and whole steps. Contains both b9 and #9, the natural 3rd, #11, natural 5th, natural 13, and b7 — making it incredibly versatile over dominant chords. There are only 3 unique diminished scales.
common_usage: Over dominant 7th chords, especially 7b9 and 13b9. The 8 notes give you many color options. A favorite of players like Pat Martino, John Scofield, and Kurt Rosenwinkel.

name: Bebop Dominant Scale
notes_in_c: C D E F G A Bb B
description: The Mixolydian scale with an added natural 7th (passing tone between b7 and root). This 8-note scale ensures that chord tones (1, 3, 5, b7) land on downbeats when playing eighth notes, creating a smooth, flowing sound that outlines the harmony automatically. This is the fundamental insight of bebop.
common_usage: Over dominant 7th chords when playing eighth-note lines. The added passing tone keeps chord tones on the beats. Essential for bebop, hard bop, and any swing-based improvisation.

name: Bebop Major Scale
notes_in_c: C D E F G G# A B
description: The major scale with an added #5 (passing tone between 5 and 6). Like the bebop dominant scale, this ensures chord tones land on downbeats. Provides smooth chromatic movement in the upper part of the scale.
common_usage: Over major 7th chords when playing bebop-style eighth-note lines. Keeps chord tones (1, 3, 5, 7) on the beats.

name: Minor Pentatonic
description: The most universal guitar scale — 5 notes, no 'wrong' notes when used correctly. The backbone of blues, rock, and much of popular music. In jazz, it's used as a melodic simplification tool and for pentatonic superimposition.
common_usage: Over minor 7th chords, dominant 7th chords (for a blues sound), and as a starting point for pentatonic superimposition in jazz.

name: Major Pentatonic
description: The 'happy' pentatonic. 5 notes from the major scale with the 4th and 7th removed (the two notes that create the most tension). Used in country, pop, and jazz for melodic, consonant lines.
common_usage: Over major chords and dominant chords for a consonant, melodic sound. Great for pentatonic superimposition: play D major pentatonic over Cmaj7 to highlight extensions (9, #11, 13).
